currentText:
St Mary’s House Dental Care is a long-established private practice in Shoreham-by-Sea. We focus on careful planning, calm delivery, and dentistry that makes sense for the long term.

We look after everyday oral health and also support complex cases involving tooth wear, missing teeth, implant-supported restorations, heavily restored mouths, and bite-related problems.

Appointments are structured so you understand what we’ve found, what it means, and what your realistic options are. If you’re anxious, short on time, or simply want things explained properly, we’ll take a measured approach and agree the next step together.
Overview
Dentistry planned carefully, delivered properly

Care at St Mary’s House is built around time, explanation, and respect for every patient’s circumstances.

We provide general, restorative, implant, orthodontic, and aesthetic dentistry, but we don’t rush decisions or push treatment. Appointments are unhurried, explanations are clear, and choices are made collaboratively.

We’ve cared for patients from Shoreham-by-Sea and surrounding towns for many years. Many stay with us long-term — not because they need ongoing treatment, but because they value consistency and knowing who is looking after them.

Dentistry works best when your dentist understands your history, priorities, and concerns. That continuity matters whether you’re visiting for routine care, managing dental wear over time, or planning something more involved.

Clinical depth with steady hands

Your first visit is about listening, understanding your concerns, and gathering the information needed to guide you properly. You don’t need to know where to start. We’ll take things step by step.

Where treatment is required, options are explained clearly, including benefits, limitations, costs, and timescales. From there, you can decide how — or whether — to proceed, with support available at every stage.
Patient journey
A clear, supportive first step

Good dentistry isn’t just about a single procedure. It’s about understanding bite, function, health, aesthetics, and long-term stability — and planning accordingly.

We take a conservative, evidence-led approach. When care becomes complex or irreversible — implants, extractions, root canal treatment, veneers, larger restorative plans — we slow things down, map out options clearly, and proceed step by step with your comfort and understanding at the centre.
Clinical philosophy
Care that values planning as much as precision

Care pathway
How care works here

Many patients come to us after years of piecemeal dentistry, unresolved problems, or uncertainty about what should happen next. These cases need structure, not speed.

Our approach brings disciplines together — restorative, orthodontic, implant, and digital planning — so treatment is sequenced sensibly and reviewed carefully. For missing teeth, that may include implant-supported restorations or implant-retained dentures, planned with stability, comfort, and ease of maintenance in mind.

The aim is a clearer path forward before anything irreversible begins.

St Mary’s House Dental Care is a long-established private dental practice in Shoreham-by-Sea.

We work in a calm, clinician-led way: careful assessment, clear explanation, and treatment planned for long-term stability rather than quick fixes.

If you’re nervous about dentistry, or you’ve had mixed experiences in the past, we’ll take things at a pace that feels manageable and explain what we’re doing as we go.

fingerprint.endsWith: hat we’re doing as we go.

currentText: About St Mary’s House Dental Care

How we work is simple, even if the dentistry isn’t.

We start with understanding the problem properly before talking about solutions. We explain options in plain English, including limits and trade-offs. Where it helps outcomes and costs, we plan treatment in stages. And we focus on comfort, fit, and long-term maintenance — not hype.

fingerprint.startsWith: How we work is simple, ev

currentText: An independent practice by choice

The practice has been part of the Shoreham area for many years, and the building itself reflects that history.

Dentistry has changed a lot over time, but the principles haven’t: careful diagnosis, sensible planning, and work you can live with comfortably. We continue to improve how we assess, plan, and deliver care, while keeping the experience calm and straightforward.
A practice built on relationships

Good dentistry should feel understandable and unrushed.

Whether you need a simple check-up or more involved restorative work, our job is to help you make clear decisions you’ll still feel comfortable with in five and ten years’ time.
Part of Shoreham, not just located in it

Most posts are written to help you make sense of common dental concerns, what tends to cause them, and what sensible next steps usually look like. From time to time we’ll also explain how planning, scanning and modern materials can make treatment more predictable.

Everything here is general information. It can be a useful starting point, but it can’t replace advice tailored to you after an examination. If something you read here raises questions about your own teeth or gums, we’re happy to talk it through at an appointment.

Getting in touch should feel straightforward.

Whether you’d like to arrange an appointment, ask a question, or talk something through before deciding what to do next, our team will help guide you calmly and clearly.

There’s no obligation to proceed with treatment simply by contacting us. Many people get in touch because they want to understand their options, what an initial appointment involves, or whether something sounds urgent.

We’re a private dental practice based in Shoreham-by-Sea, and we see patients with a wide range of concerns — from routine check-ups to more complex dental problems.

If you feel unsure, or it’s been a while since you last saw a dentist, that’s very common. Let us know when you contact us and we can take things at a pace that feels manageable.

You’re welcome to contact the practice by phone or by using the enquiry form on this page.

If your question is straightforward, our reception team can usually help directly. If it’s more clinical, we’ll make sure it’s passed to the right person.

The documents on this page are provided to support your care with us.

They may include aftercare guidance, treatment information, and practical notes that are useful before or after an appointment. Not every document will apply to everyone, and some information is only relevant in certain situations.

If you’ve been given a specific document by the team, you can usually find it here. If you’re unsure which information applies to you, or if something isn’t clear, we’re always happy to help explain.

Written guidance is helpful, but it can’t replace a proper conversation or clinical assessment. If something doesn’t feel right, or you have concerns following treatment, it’s important to contact the practice rather than relying only on written information.

The documents here are reviewed from time to time, so you may notice updates as guidance changes.

---
Overview
Care downloads

Dental fees vary because treatment depends on the condition of the teeth and gums, the complexity of care, and the time and materials required.

Two people having what sounds like the same treatment may need very different levels of care.

Because of this, we avoid giving fixed prices without first seeing you.
Overview
Fees and planning

Before any treatment is started, we take time to understand what you actually need. This usually involves an examination, appropriate X-rays or scans, and a discussion about your priorities.

Where treatment is straightforward, fees can often be estimated quite accurately. For more complex or staged care, we will explain the likely range and the factors that could affect it.

You will always be given a written treatment plan before going ahead, and nothing is carried out without your agreement.
How we approach fees
How we approach fees

If you are unsure whether a particular treatment is appropriate, or simply want to understand likely costs before booking, please get in touch.

Initial conversations are about understanding your situation, not committing you to treatment.
Why dentistry costs vary
Why dentistry costs vary

Our fees are not just for the treatment you receive on the day. They reflect the full clinical process, which may include:

• detailed assessment and diagnosis
• digital imaging and planning where appropriate
• high-quality materials and laboratory work
• time for careful, unhurried delivery
• follow-up care and review

This approach supports safe, well-planned care that is tailored to you — not simply completed quickly.

fingerprint.startsWith: Our fees are not just for

currentText: What our fees include
What our fees include

Not all dental treatment needs to be done at once.

In many cases, care can be planned in stages, allowing you to prioritise what matters most and spread treatment over time. This approach often leads to better long-term outcomes and more manageable costs.

We are happy to talk through different options and help you decide what feels right for you.
Staged treatment and flexible planning
Staged treatment and flexible planning

Payment is usually taken at the time of treatment. For larger treatment plans, finance options may be available to help spread the cost.

If finance is something you would like to consider, we can explain how it works and whether it may be suitable for your situation.

We’ll always explain costs clearly before treatment starts, so you’re not faced with surprises.

Feedback and updates

If something hasn’t felt right, we want to know.

We take complaints seriously and we aim to resolve concerns fairly, calmly, and as quickly as possible.

If you feel able, please raise the issue with us directly first. Most concerns can be resolved promptly once we understand what has happened and what you’re worried about.
Overview
Raising concerns

This page explains how to raise a concern or complaint about care you have received, and how we handle it.

It is not a substitute for clinical advice. If you have pain, swelling, trauma, or an urgent problem, please contact the practice so we can help you quickly.
What this page covers

- Tell us what happened and what outcome you’re hoping for.
- We will listen, review what we can, and respond clearly.
- If we need time to investigate properly, we will tell you the expected timescales.
- You can raise concerns in writing, by email, or by speaking to the team.
Key points in plain English

You can bring someone with you to support you if you prefer.

If you would like your complaint handled by a specific person, let us know and we will do our best to accommodate this, depending on availability and the nature of the concern.

We keep complaints confidential and handle them in line with professional and legal obligations.
Your choices and controls

The best first step is to contact the practice directly so we can understand the issue and try to resolve it.

If you prefer to put things in writing, email is often the clearest way to set out what happened and what you would like us to do next.

This page explains how cookies and similar technologies may be used on our website. Cookies are small files stored on your device that help a site work properly, remember preferences, and (where enabled) provide usage insights. Some cookies are essential for core site functions and security. Others may be used for analytics to understand which pages are visited and how the site performs. Optional cookies, if used, can be managed through your browser settings. You can also manage cookies through your browser settings, although this may affect how some features behave.

currentText: Updates to this page

This privacy notice explains how St Mary’s House Dental Care uses and protects personal information.

We are committed to handling personal data responsibly and in line with UK data protection law.

We may collect personal information when you contact the practice, book an appointment, complete forms, or use this website.

This can include contact details, appointment information, and technical data such as IP address and browser type when you use the site.

Personal information is used to provide dental care, manage appointments, communicate with you, and meet our legal and professional obligations.

We do not sell personal data and only share information where necessary for care, administration, or legal reasons.

We take appropriate steps to keep personal information secure, including access controls and secure systems.

Data is kept only for as long as required by clinical, legal, or regulatory obligations.

You have rights under UK data protection law, including the right to access your information and request corrections.

If you have questions about how your data is used, or wish to exercise your rights, please contact the practice.

This privacy notice may be updated from time to time to reflect changes in law or how we operate.

The current version will always be available on this website.
Overview
Privacy and your information

We may collect information you provide when you contact us or book an appointment (for example, name, contact details and appointment-related information). When you use the website, it may also collect limited technical information needed for it to function properly.
What information we collect
We use personal information to manage appointments, respond to enquiries, provide dental care where appropriate, and meet legal and professional obligations.
Why we use it
We do not sell personal data. We only share information when it’s necessary for care, administration, or legal reasons, and we aim to share the minimum needed.

These website terms explain how you may use this site and what the information here is (and isn’t) intended for.

The content on this website is provided for general information only. It is not a substitute for a dental examination, diagnosis, or personalised advice.

If you have a dental problem, pain, swelling, trauma, or anything you’re worried about, please contact the practice so we can advise you appropriately.
Overview
Using this website

These terms apply to your use of this website. They cover the general informational nature of the content, responsible use of the site, and how to contact us if you have questions.

They do not replace the terms you agree to when you become a patient, and they do not form a clinical relationship on their own.
What this page covers

- You can browse and use this website for personal, lawful purposes.
- The information is general and may not apply to your specific situation.
- Dentistry often needs an examination and sometimes X-rays or scans before advice is reliable.
- If you need urgent help, please contact us rather than relying on website information.
Key points in plain English

You are welcome to print or share pages for personal use, but please don’t copy large parts of the site for commercial use.

If you’re making decisions about treatment, the safest route is always an appointment where we can assess you properly and explain options, limits, and likely maintenance.
Your choices and controls

If you have questions about the website content, or you believe something is unclear or out of date, please contact the practice and we’ll do our best to help.

For clinical concerns (pain, swelling, broken teeth, lost restorations, or anything urgent), please call us so we can guide you to the right next step.

It spreads the cost of routine dental care and encourages regular review, prevention, and early intervention where needed.

Our smile gallery shares examples of treatments carried out at St Mary’s House Dental Care, with the aim of helping you understand what different options can look like in real life. Every smile is unique and results vary, so these cases are here to support informed conversations — not to promise a specific outcome. Where we share before-and-after images, we do so with consent and with context about the type of work involved. If you see a result you like, we can discuss whether a similar approach is clinically suitable for you, and what the planning would involve.
Overview
Smile transformations, simplified

Each case includes a brief summary of the starting point, the type of treatment provided, and the kind of planning involved.

Where before-and-after images are shown, they are there to help you understand what may be possible — not to suggest you will get an identical result. Photographs also don’t show everything that matters in dentistry, such as bite, gum health, long-term maintenance, or the stability of the underlying teeth.

If you see a style of outcome you like, we can talk through whether a similar approach is clinically suitable for you and what would need to be assessed first.

Dentistry works best when it’s delivered by people who know each other well.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, we’re a small, experienced team who work together every day — not a rotating cast. That continuity matters. It affects communication, planning, and how calmly care is delivered.

Patients often tell us they value recognising familiar faces and feeling understood rather than processed.
Team
Our team

Good outcomes in dentistry depend on more than individual skill.

They rely on clear communication between clinicians and nurses, shared standards of care, and consistency in how patients are looked after. Our team works closely across examinations, hygiene, restorative care, and longer-term treatment planning.

That collaboration reduces errors, avoids duplication, and makes appointments feel more settled.

Video spotlight

Dr Nick Maxwell
Principal Dentist · Restorative, Aesthetic & Digital Dentistry

I’m Dr Nick Maxwell, principal dentist at St Mary’s House Dental Care in Shoreham-by-Sea.
I’ve been practising dentistry since 1998 and have spent much of my career focused on the kind of dentistry that needs calm judgment: complex restorative work, aesthetic planning, bite stability, and carefully selected implant and orthodontic cases.
My aim is simple: help patients make decisions they can feel good about years from now — not just next month.
Profile intro

Qualifications and training

I hold:
• BDS (King’s College London)
• MSc Restorative & Aesthetic Dentistry
• PGDip Orthodontics & Facial Orthopaedics
I’ve also completed implant surgical training and intensive implant placement training (Cairo, 2014).
Qualifications matter, but what matters most is what they change in day-to-day care: the ability to plan, select cases carefully, and avoid unnecessary intervention.
Credentials

How I work

Dentistry can be rushed. It can also be over-sold. I’m not interested in either.
My approach is deliberately planning-first and case-by-case:
• We start with diagnosis and stability, not “what you’d like done”
• We talk honestly about trade-offs and limitations
• I’m happy to recommend the simplest sensible option — and equally happy to advise against treatment that isn’t in your long-term interest
That’s what I mean by “sleep-at-night dentistry”.
Care philosophy

Digital dentistry and 3D planning

Over the past several years I’ve developed a strong focus on digital dentistry — not as a gimmick, but as a way to plan more precisely and communicate more clearly.
This includes:
• digital planning workflows for restorative and implant cases
• CBCT-based assessment where appropriate
• designing and 3D-printing surgical guides for guided implant placement
• a strong emphasis on predictability and maintainability
Technology doesn’t replace clinical judgment — but used properly, it helps reduce uncertainty and improves decision-making.

Patients often come to see me when they want a calm, honest second opinion, a long-term plan rather than a quick fix, and careful aesthetic work that still respects tooth structure. If you’re looking for rushed dentistry, I won’t be the right fit. If you want careful, clinician-led planning, you probably will.

Sara Burden is a Dental Hygienist at St Mary’s House Dental Care, with over 30 years’ experience in dental hygiene. She qualified from Birmingham Dental School in 1990 and has worked across general practice, specialist care and research settings.

Patients commonly see Sara for periodontal care, maintenance appointments and support with gum health, particularly where long-term stability is essential. She is known for her gentle, thorough approach and for helping patients feel at ease, especially those who may feel anxious about hygiene treatment.

Sara plays an important role within the practice’s preventative and long-term care philosophy, working closely with the dentists to support restorative and implant treatment planning through ongoing periodontal health.

fingerprint.startsWith: Sara Burden is a Dental H

currentText: Profile intro

Sara qualified as a dental hygienist from Birmingham Dental School in 1990. Over the course of her career, she has gained extensive experience in general dental practice, specialist environments and dental research.

She has a particular interest in the management of acute gum conditions and in the relationship between oral health, nutrition and systemic wellbeing. Sara takes a holistic view of periodontal care, supporting patients with practical, evidence-based advice alongside clinical treatment.

She remains committed to maintaining high professional standards and keeps her knowledge up to date through regular continuing professional development, ensuring her approach reflects current best practice in periodontal care. GDC: 3966.
Credentials

Sara’s approach to dental hygiene is preventative, methodical and patient-focused. She believes effective periodontal care relies on understanding, consistency and realistic guidance that patients can apply between visits.

She takes time to explain findings clearly, discuss contributing factors and demonstrate techniques where helpful, allowing patients to feel informed rather than overwhelmed. Appointments are unhurried and adapted to individual comfort levels, with particular consideration given to patients who may feel nervous or sensitive.

Sara places strong emphasis on long-term maintenance, recognising that stable gum health is essential for both natural teeth and restorative work. Her aim is to support predictable, sustainable oral health outcomes through collaborative care and clear communication.
Care philosophy

Sara values the long-term relationships that develop through preventative care and enjoys supporting patients as their oral health improves over time. She takes particular satisfaction in helping people feel more comfortable, confident and informed about their gum health.

Dr Sylvia Krafft is an Associate Dentist at St Mary’s House Dental Care in Shoreham-by-Sea. She qualified as a Zahnarzt (Dental Surgeon) at the University of Cologne and has over 20 years’ experience working in general dentistry across Germany, the United States and the United Kingdom.

Patients commonly see Dr Krafft for general dental care, prevention-focused treatment and aesthetic dentistry delivered with a conservative, minimally invasive approach. She has a particular interest in improving the appearance of teeth in ways that remain biologically sound and appropriate for long-term oral health.

Since relocating to the UK in 2009, Dr Krafft has worked extensively in both NHS and private practice. Her international background allows her to draw on a broad range of clinical perspectives, supporting thoughtful, individualised care for patients of all ages.

She is especially valued by patients who want careful explanations, realistic expectations and treatment that enhances confidence without unnecessary intervention.

fingerprint.startsWith: Dr Sylvia Krafft is an As

currentText: Profile intro

Dr Krafft qualified as a Zahnarzt (Dental Surgeon) at the University of Cologne (Zahnklinik Köln) in 2001. In addition to her dental qualification, she is also a trained dental technician, giving her a detailed understanding of dental materials, morphology and precision.

Early in her career, she worked in general practice in Germany before moving to the United States, where she volunteered at a dental charity hospital in Miami. This experience reinforced her commitment to ethical, patient-centred care and to providing treatment that balances clinical need with individual circumstance.

Since moving to the UK in 2009, Dr Krafft has gained over 15 years’ experience across NHS and private dentistry. She has developed a particular interest in aesthetic dentistry delivered conservatively, focusing on proportion, harmony and tooth preservation rather than aggressive cosmetic change.

Her background as both clinician and technician informs a careful, detail-led approach, especially when planning aesthetic or restorative work. GDC: 174528.
Credentials

Dr Krafft’s clinical approach is centred on prevention, minimal intervention and patient understanding. She believes that aesthetic dentistry should enhance natural features rather than replace them, and that successful outcomes depend on respecting the biology of teeth and gums.

She prioritises conservative solutions wherever possible and takes time to explain options clearly, including what can be achieved predictably and what may introduce unnecessary risk. Patients are encouraged to make informed decisions at a pace that feels comfortable, with realistic expectations set from the outset.

For patients who feel anxious, Dr Krafft focuses on building trust through calm communication and a supportive, unhurried approach. Treatment is adapted to individual comfort levels, and patients are kept fully informed and in control throughout their care.

Her dual training as a dentist and dental technician supports a precise, considered approach to both aesthetic and functional treatment. Long-term oral health, stability and maintainability are always prioritised over short-term cosmetic change.
Care philosophy

Dr Krafft values dentistry for the balance it offers between technical precision and human connection. She enjoys helping patients feel more confident about their smile in a way that remains natural and sustainable, and takes particular satisfaction in supporting patients who appreciate careful, considered care rather than rushed solutions.

Digital dentistry FAQs
We recommend porcelain for cases needing maximum longevity, high gloss, or colour stability. Printed options are useful for provisional stages or conservative veneers when appropriate.
When do you recommend porcelain instead of printing?
Digital scanning and in-house production shorten turnaround times; we share a range after your assessment and schedule fit appointments accordingly.
How fast can printed dentures or guards be ready?
We pair them with occlusion checks, hygiene plans, and torque reviews. You’ll know the follow-up cadence before treatment begins.
Do printed implant restorations need different maintenance?
Yes. We review shape, bite, and shade options with you, then adjust the plan before production.
Can designs be adjusted after I see the preview?
Digital files let us reproduce or adjust quickly if needed, with clinician review to avoid repeating issues.
What about repairs or remakes?

Calm, clinician-led control

3D and digital dentistry refers to the way we plan, design, and carry out dental treatment using detailed digital scans rather than relying only on traditional impressions and estimates.

For patients, this means we can see your teeth, bite, and jaw in far greater detail before treatment starts. Digital scans allow us to plan carefully, explain options clearly, and reduce guesswork at every stage.

This technology supports safer planning, clearer communication, and more predictable outcomes. It does not replace clinical judgement or experience — it supports it.

Who benefits

currentText: You are able to see proposed treatment plans, understand why a particular approach is recommended, and ask informed questions before decisions are made. Planning happens in advance, which often reduces adjustments, remakes, or surprises later on.

fingerprint.startsWith: You are able to see propo

currentText: For many treatments, digital workflows also allow for fewer appointments and more accurate fitting restorations, although this depends on the type of care involved.
Patients who want predictable, visual planning
Your digital pathway
digital-dentistry-timeline
We use 3D and digital planning across a wide range of treatments, including crowns and bridges, dental implants, orthodontic aligners, and more complex restorative work.
Not every treatment requires digital planning, and it is not used automatically. We recommend it when it adds clarity, accuracy, or safety to your care.
Your dentist will explain whether digital planning is appropriate for your situation and why.
Timelines vary by case complexity; we share ranges and review points upfront.
Clear checkpoints from scan to maintenance

Instead of taking physical moulds, we use digital scanners and imaging to build a precise three-dimensional picture of your teeth and mouth.

These scans are used to plan treatments such as crowns, implants, aligners, or complex restorations. Because the information is visual, we can show you what we see and talk through options in a way that is easier to understand.

Digital planning helps us check spacing, bite relationships, and fit before treatment begins, rather than discovering issues part-way through.
What we can make in-house
digital-dentistry-technology
Precision outputs, clinician-reviewed
Aftercare & considerations
digital-dentistry-aftercare
Digital imaging allows us to assess structures that are difficult to judge by eye alone, such as tooth position below the gum or bone levels around teeth.
When X-ray-based scans are used, they are prescribed carefully and only when clinically justified. We follow UK radiation guidelines and always balance benefit against exposure.
Digital tools support careful planning, but they do not replace clinical checks, consent discussions, or hands-on assessment.
Long-term fit backed by maintenance
Digital dentistry FAQs
We recommend porcelain for cases needing maximum longevity, high gloss, or colour stability. Printed options are useful for provisional stages or conservative veneers when appropriate.
When do you recommend porcelain instead of printing?
Digital scanning and in-house production shorten turnaround times; we share a range after your assessment and schedule fit appointments accordingly.
How fast can printed dentures or guards be ready?
We pair them with occlusion checks, hygiene plans, and torque reviews. You’ll know the follow-up cadence before treatment begins.
Do printed implant restorations need different maintenance?
Yes. We review shape, bite, and shade options with you, then adjust the plan before production.
Can designs be adjusted after I see the preview?
Digital files let us reproduce or adjust quickly if needed, with clinician review to avoid repeating issues.
What about repairs or remakes?
digital-dentistry-faq
Answers before you choose

Printed veneer FAQs

Longevity depends on bite forces, tooth position, habits such as grinding, and how the restorations are looked after. We’ll plan for durability and talk you through realistic expectations for your individual case.
How long do digitally designed or printed veneers last?
They are typically the most affordable veneer route. We explain how costs differ from composite bonding and porcelain so you can choose the right stage for you.
What do printed veneers cost?
Suitability is decided after a full assessment of enamel, alignment, bite forces, and aesthetic goals. If printed veneer restorations aren’t right for you, we’ll recommend a better alternative.
Who are printed veneers suitable for?
Expect hygiene visits, occasional polishing, and night guard wear if you clench. Printed veneers can stain or wear sooner than porcelain, so refreshes are planned into your care.
What maintenance do printed veneers need?

Yes. Digital previews and printed mock sets let you assess length, symmetry, and shade. We can also discuss whitening or a combined smile makeover if that better matches your goals (/treatments/full-smile-makeover).

Ceramic (porcelain) veneers and digitally printed veneer restorations are made from different materials and produced in different ways. Ceramic veneers are a long-established option. Printed restorations use modern scanning and printing technology to create precise, ultra-thin restorations for carefully selected cases. The right choice depends on your bite, goals, and long-term plan — not one material ‘winning’ for everyone.
Porcelain veneers vs digitally designed / 3D printed veneers
printed-veneers-comparison
Ceramic veneers (porcelain) — A long-established, lab-made option with excellent aesthetics and colour stability. Often chosen where a definitive ceramic solution is appropriate.

Digitally printed veneer restorations — A modern digital restorative option produced from scans and 3D printing workflows. Can be highly conservative in suitable cases and is planned around individual bite and function.
Printed vs ceramic veneers — what’s different?

We offer advanced digitally designed veneer restorations using high-precision scanning and 3D printing technology. These restorations are custom designed from digital scans and printed from biocompatible dental resins used internationally in advanced restorative dentistry. The aim is a precise fit, controlled thickness, and a conservative approach — always guided by clinical judgement and careful case selection.
Your pathway
printed-veneers-process
Precision fit from digital scans — We design from detailed 3D scans so the restoration is planned in relation to your tooth shape, contact points, and bite.
Ultra-thin, conservative designs (when suitable) — In the right cases, we can minimise tooth preparation and still achieve a meaningful aesthetic change.
Digitally repeatable workflow — Digital planning improves consistency and makes it easier to refine the design across appointments if needed.
Hand-finished by your clinician — Printed restorations are shaped, finished, and polished carefully by hand for a natural, bespoke result.
Case selection + bite planning first — We assess bite forces, tooth position, enamel, and habits (like grinding) before recommending printed veneer restorations.
Staged treatment planning options — Depending on your situation, these restorations may be used as long-term or medium-term aesthetic solutions, or as part of a staged plan.

fingerprint.endsWith: as part of a staged plan.

We use biocompatible dental resins supplied for regulated dental applications and process them strictly according to manufacturer instructions. The final restoration is then finished and polished by hand to refine shape, texture, and shine. If ceramic is the better option for your goals or bite, we’ll tell you clearly.

Flexible aesthetics with careful fitting

Acrylic dentures are removable dentures made from a lightweight acrylic material and are commonly used to replace missing teeth.

They are often chosen because they are adaptable, cost-effective, and suitable in a wide range of clinical situations. Like all dentures, they involve compromise, and understanding how they function in everyday life is key to deciding whether they are the right option for you.

Before any recommendation is made, we focus on how acrylic dentures would fit your mouth, your expectations, and your day-to-day needs.
Impressions or scans to capture your bite
Wax or printed try-ins to check speech and fit

currentText: Tooth shades and shapes selected with you
Relines or soft liners available if gums change
Honest discussion of movement limits vs other materials
What they are
acrylic-dentures-overview
Custom acrylic dentures with staged checks
Who they suit
acrylic-dentures-who
Acrylic dentures may be used as a long-term solution or as a temporary step while other treatment options are considered.

They are commonly used when teeth have been lost recently, when bone or gum levels are changing, or when more complex treatments are not suitable. In some cases, they provide a practical way to restore function while keeping future options open.
Your dentist will explain why acrylic dentures are being considered in your particular case.
Adaptable for many smiles
Pathway
acrylic-dentures-process
Acrylic dentures are custom-made dentures constructed primarily from acrylic resin. They can replace some teeth (partial dentures) or all teeth in an upper or lower jaw.

fingerprint.endsWith: in an upper or lower jaw.

currentText: Because acrylic is relatively easy to adjust, these dentures are often used where flexibility is important — for example, when the mouth is still changing or when a simpler solution is appropriate.
They are removable and rely on the shape of the gums, remaining teeth, and muscle control for support.
You’ll know expected timelines, review points, and fees upfront.
From design to everyday wear

Acrylic dentures need daily cleaning to remove plaque and food debris and to protect the health of the gums.

They should be removed for cleaning and usually overnight to allow the tissues to rest. Acrylic can wear or change fit over time as the mouth changes, even if the denture itself appears intact.

Regular reviews help ensure comfort is maintained and allow small adjustments to be made when needed.

fingerprint.endsWith: s to be made when needed.

currentText: Materials & fit
acrylic-dentures-technology
Lightweight bases with clinician-guided adjustments
Aftercare & considerations
acrylic-dentures-aftercare
Wearing acrylic dentures usually involves an adjustment period. They can feel bulky at first, and eating or speaking may take time to feel natural again.
Over time, many people adapt well, but acrylic dentures do not behave like fixed teeth. Stability and comfort depend on fit, muscle control, and the shape of the supporting tissues.
Follow-up appointments are important to adjust the fit and address any pressure areas as your mouth adapts.
Looking after acrylic dentures
FAQs
Acrylic dentures can last for years, but fit and function change as the mouth changes. Relines, repairs, or replacement may be needed over time.
How long do acrylic dentures last?
Acrylic dentures can feel bulkier at first, and it takes time to adapt. We adjust the fit and outline what to expect during the settling-in period.
Will acrylic dentures feel bulky?
Yes, repairs are often possible if a denture chips or fractures. We’ll explain how to protect them and what to do if damage occurs.

fingerprint.endsWith: t to do if damage occurs.

currentText: Can acrylic dentures be repaired?
Some patients use a small amount for reassurance, especially for lower dentures. We prioritise fit first and discuss implant support if you want more stability.
Do I need adhesive?
acrylic-dentures-faq

Anti-wrinkle treatments are used to soften the appearance of certain facial lines by temporarily relaxing specific muscles that contribute to them over time.

These treatments are medical procedures and should be approached carefully. A thorough consultation is essential to assess suitability, discuss expectations, and explain how treatment works.

Our focus is on subtle, natural-looking outcomes that respect facial balance rather than dramatic change.
Assessment of facial movement and medical history before prescribing
Conservative dosing tailored to your goals and muscle activity
Review appointments to monitor comfort and refine only when safe

currentText: Sterile technique with single-use needles and antisepsis at each site
Safety guidance on expected effects, rare adverse events, and how to contact us quickly
Prescriber-led treatment with transparent risks

Anti-wrinkle treatments do not treat all types of facial lines and will not replace skin care, volume treatments, or surgical options where these are more appropriate.

As with any medical procedure, there are risks and possible side effects. These are discussed in full during consultation.

Treatment is only provided following appropriate assessment, discussion, and informed consent.
Full medical history, medicines, and contraindication checks
Facial mapping to balance doses and avoid brow or lid heaviness
Explanation of onset (usually several days) and duration (often up to 3–4 months)
Written aftercare and review scheduling before you leave

anti-wrinkle-who-for
Suitability depends on individual facial anatomy, medical history, and personal goals.
Anti-wrinkle treatments may not be appropriate for everyone. Certain medical conditions, medications, or life stages can affect whether treatment is advised.
We carry out a full medical consultation before recommending any treatment and will advise honestly if it is not suitable — including when doing nothing is the better option.

fingerprint.startsWith: We carry out a full medic

currentText: For suitable patients seeking gentle softening
Your pathway
anti-wrinkle-process
Anti-wrinkle treatments work by reducing muscle activity in targeted areas of the face. This can soften lines that form through repeated facial movement.
The effect is temporary and develops gradually over several days. Treatment does not stop the ageing process, but it can soften the appearance of certain lines for a limited period.
Your practitioner will explain which areas may benefit and what level of change is realistic.
Results are temporary and depend on your response. We avoid high doses or rushed top-ups to protect facial function.
Consult, prescribe, treat, and review

We plan doses per muscle group, favouring multiple micro-injections to distribute medicine evenly. Needle gauge and depth are chosen to respect underlying vessels and avoid diffusion into unintended areas.
Dose planning & technique
anti-wrinkle-technology
Prescription anti-wrinkle vials prepared with micro-needles
Mapped injection points for balanced results
Aftercare & risks
anti-wrinkle-aftercare
Treatment appointments are typically brief and involve carefully placed injections in specific facial muscles.
Results are not immediate and usually develop over several days. Effects are temporary and gradually wear off, meaning repeat treatment may be required to maintain the result.
We explain the process, aftercare, and potential risks before treatment begins so you can make an informed decision.
Clear guidance and prompt escalation routes
Anti-wrinkle FAQs
Results develop gradually and wear off over time. The duration varies between individuals, and we discuss realistic expectations during consultation.
How long do results last?
Our approach focuses on careful assessment and conservative dosing. The aim is a softer appearance while maintaining natural facial movement.
Will I look frozen?
Most patients report brief pinpricks. Topical anaesthetic can be provided if needed, and we use fine needles to reduce discomfort.
Does it hurt?
We often stage anti-wrinkle care with fillers, skin boosters, or polynucleotides when suitable. Sequencing is planned in consultation to keep safety first.
Can I combine this with other treatments?

If you’ve chipped a tooth, cracked a corner, or something feels sharp or painful, it’s worth getting it checked promptly.

Some problems look small but involve deeper cracks or exposed dentine, which can lead to sensitivity, infection, or a larger fracture.

We’ll assess what’s happened, explain what we can see, and recommend the least invasive repair that keeps the tooth stable.

emergency_chipped_overview
Broken, chipped or cracked teeth

Teeth can chip or crack for lots of reasons — biting something hard, an old filling giving way, grinding, or an accident.

Sometimes it’s mainly cosmetic. Sometimes it’s an early warning that the tooth is under stress.

If you’re unsure, we’d rather you call and ask. We can advise whether it sounds urgent and what to do in the meantime.

currentText: What to do now

A chip or crack isn’t always an emergency, but it can change quickly.

Small fractures can spread, and exposed dentine can become very sensitive. In some cases, cracks allow bacteria to reach the nerve, leading to infection.

Seeing you early gives us more conservative options — and helps prevent the problem turning into a bigger repair.

currentText: emergency_chipped_importance
Protect the tooth
Why it’s worth checking

Treatment depends on where the crack is, how deep it goes, and how much tooth is missing.

Options may include smoothing a sharp edge, a bonded repair (composite), replacing or reshaping an old filling, or protecting the tooth with an onlay or crown.

If the nerve is involved, root canal treatment may be needed — but we only recommend that when it’s clearly indicated.
emergency_chipped_options

Restorative options
Possible treatments
Sometimes a small chip can wait a short time, but it’s best to get advice. Chips can expose dentine, increase sensitivity, or develop into a larger fracture. Call us and we’ll guide you on timing.
Can a chipped tooth wait?

Not always. We usually start with the least invasive repair that keeps the tooth stable. That may be smoothing, a bonded repair, or replacing a filling. A crown or onlay is recommended when the tooth needs extra protection.

Cracked tooth FAQs

Grinding and clenching (bruxism) can place heavy forces on teeth, restorations and jaw joints, often without you realising. Common signs include tooth wear, fractures, sensitive teeth, morning headaches or jaw tension. We assess wear patterns, bite contacts and muscle tenderness, then discuss practical ways to reduce damage. A custom night guard is often recommended to protect teeth during sleep, and we’ll explain what it can and cannot do. Because bruxism is frequently linked to stress, sleep patterns or airway factors, ongoing review can be helpful if symptoms persist or are changing.

currentText:
Three-dimensional scanning allows us to see dental structures in more detail than traditional two-dimensional X-rays.

CBCT (cone beam computed tomography) provides a 3D view of teeth, bone, nerves, and surrounding anatomy. It’s used selectively, when additional information genuinely helps with diagnosis or planning.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, CBCT scanning is used to support careful decision-making — not as a routine step for every patient.

Supports careful decision-making, not routine scanning

currentText: When CBCT scanning may be recommended

Unlike traditional X-rays, CBCT scans show structures in three dimensions.

This can help us assess bone thickness and shape, the position of nerves and sinuses, the extent of infection or fractures, and how teeth relate to surrounding structures.

Having this information upfront helps reduce uncertainty and improve planning accuracy.

Children’s dentistry is centred on prevention, early diagnosis and helping children feel comfortable in the dental setting. We keep appointments calm and age-appropriate, taking time to explain what we’re doing in a way that builds confidence rather than fear. Regular reviews allow us to monitor tooth development, bite changes and oral hygiene as children grow. We also give practical advice on diet, fluoride use, brushing and habits such as thumb sucking, which can affect long-term oral health. If treatment is needed, we plan it carefully with comfort and cooperation in mind, so visits remain manageable and positive.

Children’s dentistry FAQs
We’re happy to see children as soon as their first teeth appear or by their first birthday. Early visits help them get used to the chair and let us spot any early issues.
When should my child first visit?
Most children benefit from 6-monthly check-ups, but we may recommend shorter intervals if decay risk is higher or longer if everything is very stable.
How often should they come?
Yes. Healthy baby teeth guide adult teeth into place, support speech, and allow comfortable eating. Protecting them reduces the risk of pain, infection, or early tooth loss.
Do baby teeth really matter?
Tell us ahead of time and we’ll keep visits short, use tell-show-do, and let them stay in control. We can build up gradually with positive language and plenty of breaks.

currentText: Follow-up checks to keep fit and function steady
Slim support with clinician oversight

Chrome dentures are removable partial dentures made with a thin metal framework that supports replacement teeth.

They are used where precision, stability, and longevity matter — particularly when several natural teeth remain and can help support the denture. Chrome dentures are not simply an upgraded version of acrylic dentures; they are a different design approach with specific advantages and responsibilities.

Understanding how they work, and when they are appropriate, is essential before deciding whether this option suits you.
Detailed assessment of supporting teeth and gums
Framework design to distribute forces evenly

currentText: What they are
chrome-dentures-overview
Chrome cobalt partial dentures designed for stability
Who they suit
chrome-dentures-who
Chrome dentures are typically suitable for people who still have several healthy teeth that can support the framework.
They may not be appropriate where remaining teeth are unstable, heavily restored, or at risk of further loss. In these situations, other options may be more predictable.
We assess the condition of the remaining teeth carefully, as the long-term success of a chrome denture depends on their health.
For people wanting slimmer partials
Pathway
chrome-dentures-process
Chrome dentures use a rigid metal framework, usually made from cobalt chrome, which fits closely around the remaining teeth and gums.

This framework allows the denture to be thinner and more precisely fitted than acrylic alternatives. The design relies on existing teeth for support and stability, using carefully planned clasps or rests.
Because of this precision, chrome dentures require careful planning and accurate impressions to function well.
We map each stage so you know how the framework will feel before you commit.

fingerprint.startsWith: We map each stage so you

currentText: Planned for comfort and resilience

Compared with acrylic dentures, chrome dentures are generally more rigid and stable.

They tend to feel less bulky in the mouth, but the metal framework does not flex in the same way as acrylic. This rigidity can improve function, but it also means comfort depends heavily on accurate design and the health of the supporting teeth.

Chrome dentures are not always more comfortable by default — the outcome depends on careful assessment and planning.
Materials & fit
chrome-dentures-technology
Rigid support with careful design
Aftercare & considerations
chrome-dentures-aftercare
Chrome dentures are designed to fit precisely and can feel more secure than simpler removable dentures.
However, they are still removable appliances and require an adjustment period. Because the framework is rigid, pressure points can occur if fit or bite changes over time.
Regular reviews are important to ensure comfort and to protect the supporting teeth.
Keeping chrome dentures comfortable

We design clasp positions and tooth shades to stay discreet. In some cases we can use tooth-coloured clasps; we’ll show you options before fitting.

Chrome frameworks can last for many years, but longevity depends on fit, oral health, and how the supporting teeth change over time. Regular reviews help keep them comfortable.

currentText: Clear aligners straighten teeth using a series of custom trays that move teeth in small, planned steps. The key is diagnosis and planning: we assess your bite, gum health, tooth wear and any jaw symptoms, then use digital scans to model movement and discuss what’s realistic. Aligners can help with crowding, spacing and some bite corrections, but not every case is suitable — and retention is essential to keep results stable. We’ll also discuss where aligners fit alongside whitening, bonding or restorative work, especially if you’re planning a broader smile refresh. If aligners are recommended, you’ll receive a clear timeline, check-in plan and aftercare guidance.

Composite bonding, sometimes called dental bonding, uses tooth-coloured resin in layers to rebuild edges and refine shape with minimal drilling. We aim to preserve enamel wherever possible, plan conservatively, and explain how wear and staining are managed over time.
Tooth-preserving contouring with light surface preparation
Resins layered to match shade, translucency, and texture
Calm appointment pacing with time for review before final polishing
composite_intro
Composite bonding for measured smile refinement

Composite bonding is a conservative cosmetic treatment that improves the appearance of teeth by adding tooth-coloured resin in controlled layers.

It is commonly used to refine shape, close small gaps, or repair minor chips. Because it usually involves little or no removal of natural tooth structure, it is a lower-intervention option than treatments that require more preparation.

Suitability depends on the condition of your teeth, your bite, and what you want to achieve. We assess these carefully before recommending treatment.
composite_bonding_intro_prose
Introduction
Conservative improvements, well planned
composite_candidates
Patients wanting cosmetic improvement without irreversible drilling
Those planning staged care such as whitening or orthodontic alignment before final bonding
People exploring a cost-effective step before considering porcelain veneers
Patients who value reversible changes and measured maintenance
Who composite bonding suits best
composite_indications
Composite bonding uses a resin material that is shaped directly onto the tooth and then hardened using a curing light.

The material is colour-matched to your natural teeth and blended carefully so the result looks subtle rather than artificial. The process relies on careful shaping and finishing rather than laboratory fabrication.
Bonding is typically completed in a single visit for each area treated.
What composite bonding can and can’t do

We begin with 3D scans and clinical photographs, then design the proposed changes digitally. We share mock-ups so you can preview the direction. Guided placement and finishing maps help keep the resin precise and consistent, and support injection moulding when it offers the safest level of control.
composite_digital_planning
Digital planning
Digital smile planning and mock-up visuals
Digitally planned and guided bonding

Injection moulded composite uses a digital design and silicone or printed guides to place resin accurately. This helps keep edge lengths, embrasures, and tooth widths consistent, improves symmetry across multiple teeth, and reduces variation during placement.
Digital scans and wax-ups map planned tooth shapes before treatment
Silicone keys or printed guides control resin volume for repeatable placement
Predictable edge lengths and contact points with fewer mid-appointment adjustments
Efficient when treating several teeth together or refining symmetry after orthodontics

How composite bonding fits with other options
composite_lifespan
Composite bonding is not permanent. Over time, the material can wear, stain, or chip, particularly at the edges.
Longevity varies between individuals and depends on factors such as bite forces, habits, and oral hygiene. Maintenance or repair may be required in the future.
We discuss realistic expectations and ongoing care before treatment begins.
Longevity & maintenance
composite_not_suited
Composite bonding is best suited to patients with healthy teeth and gums who want small to moderate cosmetic changes.

It may not be suitable where there is heavy tooth wear, active grinding, or where larger structural changes are required. In these cases, alternative treatments may provide more predictable long-term results.

How long does composite bonding last?
Yes. Chips or edge wear can usually be repaired by smoothing and adding new resin, without removing the rest of the bonding.

A dental abscess is an infection that can build pressure and cause significant pain, swelling, or a bad taste.

Sometimes symptoms come and go, but the underlying infection usually needs proper assessment and treatment. Leaving it can allow the infection to spread and can make the tooth harder to save.

If you have facial swelling, difficulty swallowing, fever, or you feel generally unwell, seek urgent advice and contact us as soon as possible.

emergency_abscess_overview
Dental abscess and infection

Infections can start quietly — sometimes as a dull ache, sometimes as sensitivity, and sometimes with no pain until swelling appears.

An abscess can come from the tooth nerve, from gum disease, or from a crack or deep decay letting bacteria in.

If you’re unsure whether it’s an emergency, call us. We can advise on urgency and what to do while you’re waiting to be seen.

Common signs
emergency_abscess_steps
Contact us promptly so we can advise urgency and book the right appointment
Use normal pain relief if needed and safe for you (follow the packet guidance)
Warm salt-water rinses can help comfort (do not apply heat to facial swelling)
Avoid chewing on that side and stick to softer foods
If you develop facial swelling, fever, difficulty swallowing, or breathing problems, seek urgent medical help
What to do now

Infections are not always solved by antibiotics alone. Antibiotics can be appropriate in some situations, but the source of infection usually still needs treating.

That might mean draining the infection, cleaning and sealing the tooth with root canal treatment, treating gum infection, or removing a tooth that cannot be saved.

Our job is to assess the cause, explain the realistic options, and help you stabilise quickly — then plan longer-term care in a calm, sensible way.
emergency_abscess_importance
Act early
Why it needs proper assessment

Treatment depends on where the infection is coming from and how advanced it is.

Options may include local measures to relieve pressure, root canal treatment to try to save a tooth, periodontal (gum) treatment, or extraction when the tooth cannot be predictably restored.

If antibiotics are needed, we’ll explain why, what they can and can’t do, and what follow-up is required.
emergency_abscess_options
What we can do
Gentle relief
Possible treatments

Sometimes antibiotics are necessary, especially if there is spreading swelling or you are unwell. But an abscess usually needs the source treated as well — for example drainage, root canal treatment, gum treatment, or extraction. We’ll advise what’s appropriate after assessment.
Do I always need antibiotics?

Symptoms can ease if an abscess drains, but the infection often remains and can flare again. Leaving it can increase risk of spread and reduce the chance of saving the tooth. It’s safest to get it assessed.

A dental bridge replaces one or more missing teeth by supporting a fixed tooth (or teeth) between neighbouring teeth or implants. Suitability depends on the health of the supporting teeth, gum condition, bite forces and the size and position of the gap. We assess the area carefully, because a bridge should feel stable, cleanable and comfortable in the long term. In some cases, an implant or a removable option may be more appropriate, particularly if the neighbouring teeth are intact. If a bridge is a good fit, we’ll explain material options, preparation, expected maintenance, and how to keep the margins healthy with daily cleaning.

A dental bridge is a way of replacing one or more missing teeth by attaching a false tooth to neighbouring teeth.

A bridge can restore appearance and function, but it needs careful planning so it’s comfortable and predictable over the long term.

We’ll assess your teeth, gums, and bite and explain whether a bridge is suitable or whether other options may be more appropriate.

Dental check-ups are not just about teeth. They are an opportunity to assess your overall oral health, identify early changes, and discuss concerns before they become more complex.

As part of a routine examination, we also look for signs of oral cancer and other soft tissue conditions. These checks are visual and hands-on, and are carried out carefully at each visit.

For most people, nothing unusual is found. The value lies in consistency and familiarity — knowing what is normal for you, and noticing when something changes.

Gentle check-ups with attentive screening
dental_checkups_what_to_expect
A dental check-up involves examining your teeth, gums, bite, and existing dental work.

We look for early signs of decay, gum disease, wear, or fracture, and assess how restorations are functioning over time. X-rays may be recommended where clinically justified to see areas that cannot be assessed visually.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, crowns are planned carefully, not routinely.

currentText: Dental crown FAQs
Crowns are recommended when a tooth is cracked, heavily filled, or needs reinforcement after root canal treatment. If a more conservative option is viable, we will explain that first.
Who is a suitable candidate for a crown?
Depending on remaining tooth structure, options may include an onlay, bonded repair, or monitoring. We map crack risk and bite forces to advise when full coverage is the safer route.
Are there alternatives to a crown?
Durability depends on bite forces, hygiene, and material. We choose ceramics or metal-ceramic options to suit your case and schedule reviews to check margins and contacts over time.
How long will my crown last?

fingerprint.startsWith: How long will my crown la

currentText: Clean carefully around the margins and attend regular hygiene appointments. Bite checks help us refine contacts and spot early signs of wear or gum inflammation.
What maintenance does a crown need?
Crowns can chip, loosen, or develop decay at the margins if hygiene or bite balance is poor. We plan coverage height and consider splints if grinding is present to reduce these risks.
What are the risks or limitations?

fingerprint.startsWith: What are the risks or lim

currentText: Fees vary by material, laboratory input, and any additional planning such as scan-guided design. We provide a written estimate and outline phased treatment if needed.
How are crowns priced?
We shade-map your neighbouring teeth and use digital scans to guide shape and translucency. The aim is a natural blend that suits your smile and gumline.
Will the crown match my other teeth?

Retainers help keep teeth in their corrected positions after orthodontic treatment. Without retention, teeth naturally drift over time, even after a good result. We’ll advise on the most suitable retainer type — removable, fixed, or a combination — based on your bite, alignment and long-term stability needs. We also explain wear schedules, cleaning and what to watch for if a retainer starts to feel tight or loose. Regular checks allow us to confirm fit and function, because retainers can wear or distort gradually. The aim is stable alignment that stays comfortable and easy to maintain.
Custom-made retention after braces or aligners
Removable and fixed options explained clearly

Retainers
retainers-hero
Retainers

After teeth are moved, the supporting tissues take time to adapt.

Without retention, small changes can gradually build into noticeable relapse. This isn’t a sign that treatment has ‘failed’ — it’s a normal biological tendency.

Changes in bite and tooth position can continue throughout adult life, not just immediately after orthodontic treatment.

The aim is to maintain stability and reduce the need for repeat treatment later.

emergency_trauma_overview
Care after dental trauma or accidents

Dental trauma can range from chipped enamel to displaced or loosened teeth, fractures, and injuries to gums or supporting bone. What matters most is prompt assessment: we check tooth stability, nerve response, bite changes and soft tissue injury, and take X-rays to rule out hidden fractures. Treatment might include smoothing or repairing a chip, splinting a tooth, dressing an exposed nerve, or planning follow-up care if the tooth’s nerve is at risk. We’ll also advise on pain control and what to avoid while the area heals. If a tooth has been knocked out, time is critical — see that page for immediate steps.

Dentures are removable appliances designed to replace missing teeth and support everyday function.

They can restore appearance, support speech and chewing, and help maintain facial structure where teeth have been lost over time.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, dentures are planned carefully, with a focus on comfort, function, and realistic expectations.

Dentures are removable appliances used to replace missing teeth and restore basic function, appearance, and comfort.

They are one of several options for managing tooth loss and can be appropriate in many situations, particularly where fixed solutions are not suitable or preferred. The right approach depends on your oral health, expectations, and day-to-day needs.

Understanding what dentures can realistically provide — and where their limits are — helps you decide whether they fit your life, not just your mouth.
Partial dentures fit around remaining teeth for targeted replacement.
Full dentures replace all teeth in an arch.

Dentures may be suitable for people who have lost several or all of their teeth, particularly where bone levels, medical history, or personal preference make other treatments less appropriate.

They can also be used as a temporary or transitional solution while longer-term options are considered. Suitability is assessed on an individual basis, taking into account comfort, stability, and expected function.

Planning and fit
dentures-process
Dentures are custom-made prosthetic teeth that sit on the gums and are designed to be removed for cleaning.

They may replace some teeth (partial dentures) or all teeth in one or both jaws (full dentures). Modern dentures are designed to look natural and fit as comfortably as possible, but they remain removable appliances rather than fixed teeth.
Your dentist will explain which type may be appropriate based on your mouth, bite, and existing teeth.
Successful dentures rely on careful planning and accurate fit.
Planning and fit

Dentures need daily cleaning and regular checks to keep them fitting well and to protect the health of the gums underneath.

They should be removed for cleaning and usually at night to allow the tissues to rest. Over time, changes in the gums and jaw can affect fit, even if the dentures themselves are undamaged.

Routine reviews help catch small issues early, before comfort or fit becomes a problem.
Comfort and adjustment
dentures-technology
Comfort and adjustment
Looking after dentures
dentures-aftercare
Wearing dentures usually involves an adjustment period. Speech, eating, and comfort can feel different at first, and it takes time for the mouth and muscles to adapt.

Dentures are designed to improve function, but they do not feel or behave exactly like natural teeth. Regular reviews and adjustments are often needed to maintain comfort as the mouth changes over time.
We guide you through this process and provide advice to help you adapt gradually and comfortably.
Looking after dentures
Questions and reassurance

Eating with dentures usually takes time to adjust. Most people adapt, but certain foods can remain more challenging, especially at first. We provide guidance and review fit to improve comfort and stability.

If you’re in pain, have swelling, or you’ve damaged a tooth, an emergency appointment is about stabilising the situation.

That usually means diagnosis, getting you comfortable, reducing risk, and agreeing the next sensible step. Sometimes we can fix the problem on the day. Sometimes the safest care is staged.

We’ll explain what we can see, what’s realistic, and what you can do next — without pressure.

emergency_appointments_overview
Emergency dental appointments

Dental problems rarely happen at a convenient time.

If you’re not sure whether you need to be seen urgently, contact us. We’ll ask a few focused questions and advise timing.

If you have rapid facial swelling, fever, difficulty swallowing, or breathing problems, seek urgent medical help immediately (A&E / 999) and then let us know as soon as you can.

What to do now

Emergency care works best when we diagnose the cause properly, not just the symptom.

Pain can come from decay, infection, cracks, gum problems, or failed restorations — and the right solution depends on what we find.

Seeing you early often gives more conservative options, better comfort, and fewer repeat flare-ups.
emergency_appointments_importance
Prompt care
Why assessment matters

An emergency visit usually includes an examination and, where appropriate, X-rays to understand what’s happening under the surface.

We’ll explain the likely cause, discuss options and costs, and agree the safest next step. That might be a temporary stabilisation, a simple repair, or a plan for staged treatment.

Our aim is clarity, comfort, and a sensible route forward.

currentText: emergency_appointments_faq
Emergency appointment FAQs

If you’re in pain, have swelling, or you’ve damaged a tooth, the first job is to work out what’s urgent and what’s fixable — calmly.

Emergency care is usually about stabilising the situation: getting you comfortable, reducing risk, and planning the right longer-term repair.

If you’re unsure whether you need to be seen quickly, contact us and we’ll guide you.

emergency_dentistry_overview
Emergency dentistry

A dental emergency is any situation where pain, swelling, trauma, or infection needs prompt assessment.

Not all urgent dental problems look the same, and not all require the same response. Our role is to assess the situation, relieve pain where possible, and decide what treatment is needed to stabilise the problem safely.

If you are unsure whether your situation counts as an emergency, contacting the practice for advice is appropriate.

emergency_dentistry_triage
Dental emergencies may include severe toothache, facial swelling, dental trauma, bleeding that does not settle, or signs of infection.
Some problems feel urgent but may not require immediate treatment, while others benefit from early assessment even if pain is mild. Speaking to a dentist allows us to prioritise care appropriately.
Common reasons people contact us urgently
emergency_dentistry_steps
If you are experiencing dental pain or swelling, contact the practice as soon as you can during opening hours so we can advise on the next steps.
We will ask about your symptoms and may offer advice, an urgent appointment, or referral depending on the situation. Outside normal hours, guidance will be provided on how to access appropriate care.

fingerprint.startsWith: We will ask about your sy

currentText: If swelling affects breathing, swallowing, or causes rapidly worsening symptoms, urgent medical attention may be required.
What to do right now

Emergency dental care focuses on assessment, pain control, and stabilisation.

The aim is to address the immediate problem safely, then discuss longer-term treatment once the urgent issue has settled. In some cases, definitive treatment is not appropriate during an emergency visit.

We will explain findings clearly and outline any recommended follow-up care.

emergency_dentistry_faq
When urgent care may not be necessary

Root canal treatment is used when the nerve inside a tooth is infected or inflamed. The aim is to remove infection, preserve the remaining tooth structure, and allow the tooth to stay functional rather than be lost.

We focus on accurate diagnosis, careful cleaning and sealing of the canals, and planning how the tooth will be protected afterwards so the result is predictable and maintainable.
Clear diagnosis to confirm when a root canal is the safest option
Gentle, well-anaesthetised care with careful rubber dam isolation
Restorations that seal the tooth and reduce the risk of reinfection

currentText: Root canal FAQs
Treatment is carried out under local anaesthetic with careful isolation. Most patients feel pressure rather than pain, and any post-treatment tenderness usually settles with simple pain relief.
Will a root canal hurt?
Many cases are completed in one to two visits depending on the number of canals and whether we need to place medication between appointments.
How long does it take?
Back teeth or heavily restored teeth often benefit from a crown to prevent fractures. We will explain the best way to seal and protect your tooth.

currentText: Fixed braces move teeth using brackets and wires, offering a highly controlled way to correct alignment and bite problems. They can be a good choice where movements are more complex, where precise finishing is important, or where aligners are less suitable. We’ll assess gum health, enamel condition and bite forces before starting, then plan the sequence of movement and discuss expected timelines. During treatment, regular reviews allow adjustments to keep progress steady and safe. Retention is essential after braces, so we’ll explain retainers and long-term maintenance. If your goals include cosmetic refinements afterwards, we’ll help sequence whitening or bonding sensibly.

A full smile makeover is a way of looking at your teeth together, rather than treating individual problems in isolation. People often come to us with a mix of concerns — how their teeth look, how they function, or how they’ve changed over time.

Rather than jumping straight to treatment, we start by understanding what matters to you and what’s realistically achievable. In many cases, there is more than one way forward. Some options are simpler and more conservative, while others are more involved and take longer.

Our role is to help you understand those options clearly, including their limits, so you can decide what feels right for you.

---
Plan designed from scans and photos
Sequence options reviewed together
Checkpoints keep outcomes aligned

Smile makeovers guided by a shared plan

fingerprint.endsWith: s guided by a shared plan

currentText:
Planning is the most important part of any smile makeover. This usually involves careful examination, photographs, scans, and discussion, rather than making quick decisions.

This stage helps us see how your teeth fit together, where changes may be helpful, and where they may not be appropriate. It also allows time to talk through expectations and agree a plan that makes sense before any treatment starts.

---
full_smile_makeover_media_feature
Plan canvas
Smile plan canvas
Preview the makeover path

A full smile makeover is usually built up in stages. Each stage has a purpose, and not every stage is needed for every person. The aim is to move forward in a controlled way, rather than trying to do everything at once.

Some stages focus on creating space or alignment, others on improving appearance or repairing wear. We plan these steps carefully so that earlier treatment supports what comes later.

---
full_smile_makeover_tools_trio
We start by understanding your concerns, examining your teeth and bite, and discussing what you’d like to change. This helps identify which problems need addressing first and which can be left alone.

Where needed, early treatment may focus on alignment, bite position, or stabilising the teeth. These steps often make later cosmetic or restorative work more predictable.

Final stages may involve improving shape, colour, or repairing damage. The exact treatments depend on the plan agreed earlier and are tailored to your individual situation.

currentText: Depending on your needs, this could include orthodontic treatment, whitening, bonding, veneers, crowns or other restorative work. Not every treatment is needed for every person.
What treatments might be involved?
Timeframes vary. Some treatment plans take a few months, while others are staged over a longer period. We’ll talk this through during planning so you know what to expect.
How long does it take?
Yes. In many cases, more limited treatment can still improve appearance or function. We’ll discuss alternatives and the likely trade-offs.
Are there alternatives?
Longevity depends on the treatments used, how your teeth are looked after, and factors such as grinding or diet. Ongoing care and maintenance are important.

Home whitening uses custom-made trays and professional whitening gel to gradually brighten your teeth in a controlled way. The benefit of the home approach is precision: the trays are tailored to your teeth, the gel is used in measured doses, and you can pace treatment to manage sensitivity. We’ll check your teeth and gums first, because untreated decay, gum disease or exposed roots can make whitening uncomfortable and unpredictable. If you have existing restorations on the front teeth, we’ll explain how whitening affects the natural tooth but not the restorations, and how we can plan any replacements afterwards if needed for a balanced look.

currentText: Implant-retained dentures use a small number of implants to help stabilise a denture, making it more secure, more comfortable, and easier to manage day-to-day. This approach improves stability while keeping maintenance manageable. They are often considered a middle ground between conventional dentures and fully fixed implant teeth.

Missing teeth can change how you eat, speak and smile — and it’s not always obvious what the “right” solution is. At St Mary’s House Dental Care, implant care is clinician-led and planning-heavy: we focus on getting the foundations right so you can make a confident decision.

We’ll talk you through options (implants, bridges, dentures — or sometimes “do nothing yet”), explain the trade-offs, and recommend what’s sensible for your mouth, your health, and your long-term maintenance.

Reduced bone doesn’t automatically rule implants out. In some cases, bone grafting may be considered. We’ll explain whether it’s appropriate and the trade-offs.

Dr Nick Maxwell leads implant planning and placement at St Mary’s House Dental Care. He holds an MSc in Restorative & Aesthetic Dentistry and a PGDip in Orthodontics & Facial Orthopaedics, and has completed implant surgical training including intensive implant placement training in Cairo (2014).

He also designs and 3D prints surgical guides for guided implant placement, combining clinical judgement with digital planning where appropriate. The focus is careful case selection, clear communication, and long-term maintainability.

Dental implants can be a suitable option for many people — but they are not a “one size fits all” treatment. Outcomes depend on bone levels, gum health, bite forces, space, and the position of neighbouring teeth.

Our approach is to plan the tooth first and the implant second. Where appropriate, we use 3D imaging and digital planning to choose implant position and angulation that supports a cleanable, well-supported final crown.

A dental implant is a small post placed into the jawbone to act as a replacement tooth root. Once healed, it supports a restoration — commonly a crown for a single tooth, or a bridge or denture solution for multiple teeth.

Implant treatment is usually staged and depends on healing. We’ll explain what’s involved and what alternatives might suit you better.
