Medical factors — Some medical conditions and medications can affect healing. We’ll take a full history and advise safely.
Smoking and maintenance — Smoking and inconsistent cleaning can increase risk. We’ll be honest about what improves success.

Your implant pathway
implants-process
1) Consultation & assessment — We examine your teeth and gums, discuss your goals, and check suitability. Scans may be advised.
2) Planning — If proceeding, we plan tooth position, implant placement and timings. You’ll receive a clear treatment outline.
3) Implant placement — The implant is placed under local anaesthetic (and sedation options may be discussed where appropriate).
4) Healing phase — Healing time varies. We’ll guide you on what to expect and how to look after the area.

fingerprint.endsWith: w to look after the area.

currentText: 5) Final restoration — Once stable, we fit the crown or bridge and check bite, appearance and cleanability.
6) Reviews & maintenance — Long-term health depends on cleaning and regular reviews — we’ll support you with both.
Timelines vary. Healing time, bone quality, and your medical history guide whether we stage treatment or move more quickly.
Implant treatment, step by step

Where appropriate, we use digital scans and 3D planning to assess space, bone and bite, and to design implant placement with the final tooth in mind. We also design and 3D print surgical guides to help position implants accurately according to the plan.

Digital tools don’t replace clinical judgement — but used well, they can reduce uncertainty and improve communication.

Patient benefits

Fixed, natural feel — Implants can feel closer to natural teeth than removable options, for suitable cases.
No need to prepare neighbouring teeth — A single implant crown doesn’t usually require shaping adjacent teeth (unlike some bridge designs).
Supports bone and function — Replacing a missing root can help maintain function; we’ll explain what’s realistic for your case.
Designed for cleaning — We plan restorations to be maintainable, because “looks great” isn’t enough without long-term health.
Clear, honest planning — We explain risks, alternatives, and maintenance so you can decide with confidence.
Benefits of implant treatment

implants-aftercare
Cleaning is non-negotiable — Implants need daily cleaning just like teeth, sometimes with specific brushes or interdental aids.
Regular reviews — We monitor gums, bite and implant stability over time and act early if anything changes.
Hygiene support — Professional cleaning and coaching can protect long-term implant health.
Lifestyle factors — Smoking and uncontrolled gum disease increase risk — we’ll help you reduce avoidable problems.

Bone grafting can be used when there isn’t enough bone volume to place an implant in a stable, predictable position. The need for grafting depends on the site, how long the tooth has been missing, gum thickness, and the shape of the bone. We plan using CBCT imaging and digital scans to assess anatomy and map where the final tooth needs to sit, then discuss options such as minor grafting at implant placement or a staged approach where grafting is done first. We’ll explain healing times, how grafting affects treatment length, and what alternatives may be suitable if grafting isn’t ideal for your circumstances.

currentText: Full-arch implant treatment is designed for people with failing teeth or missing teeth who want a stable fixed option across an entire jaw. It is not one single procedure — it’s a staged plan that may involve extractions, managing infection or gum disease, careful bite planning, and deciding whether immediate fixed teeth are appropriate. We use CBCT scans and digital planning to map bone and anatomy, then design implant positions to support a predictable final bridge. We’ll explain timelines, temporary options, maintenance requirements, and what factors affect suitability such as smoking, diabetes control, tooth grinding and bone volume. If full-arch implants aren’t right for you, we’ll outline other stable alternatives.

Provisional fixed teeth so you can smile during healing
Transparent conversations about timelines, maintenance, and investment

A full-arch solution secures a custom bridge to a small number of implants (often four to six), giving a fixed alternative to loose dentures. It restores bite stability, supports clearer speech, and feels more comfortable when cleaned and maintained correctly over the long term.

A knocked-out adult tooth can sometimes be saved, but timing and how the tooth is handled matter.

If you can get advice immediately, bring the tooth with you and avoid touching the root. If it’s safe to do so, simple first aid can improve the chances of a good outcome — but after an accident it isn’t always possible to do everything perfectly.

emergency_avulsion_overview
Knocked-out tooth

Having a tooth knocked out is frightening, and it often happens alongside a fall, collision, or sports injury.

If the tooth is an adult tooth, replantation may be possible depending on timing and what has happened to the tooth and socket.

If you’re unsure whether it’s a baby tooth or an adult tooth, or there are other injuries, call us and we’ll guide you to the safest next step.

Common signs

Check for head injury, heavy bleeding, or breathing problems and seek urgent medical help if needed
Find the tooth, pick it up by the crown (not the root), and avoid scrubbing it

Call us immediately so we can advise urgency and prepare for assessment
What to do now

The tissues that help an adult tooth reattach can be damaged quickly if the tooth dries out or is handled roughly.

Even with prompt care, replantation isn’t always possible or successful. Early assessment gives the best chance of stabilising the situation and planning the next steps.

We’ll also check for associated injuries, fractures, and whether nearby teeth have been damaged or loosened.
emergency_avulsion_importance
Act quickly
Why speed matters

Treatment depends on whether the tooth is an adult tooth, how long it has been out, how it has been stored, and the condition of the socket and surrounding bone.

Options may include careful replantation and stabilisation (splinting) where appropriate, monitoring healing, and follow-up assessment. In some situations, we discuss replacement options if replantation isn’t possible.

We’ll explain the likely risks, the aftercare required, and what long-term maintenance might involve.

currentText: What to do now

When a restoration comes out, the underlying tooth is often more vulnerable than it looks.

Exposed dentine can be very sensitive, and the tooth can fracture more easily — especially if it’s already heavily filled. If there is decay or a crack underneath, delaying can reduce the options.

Seeing you early helps us protect the tooth, manage discomfort, and plan a repair that lasts.

Protect exposed teeth
Why it’s worth seeing us promptly

The right solution depends on why the restoration came out and what the tooth looks like underneath.

Options may include re-cementing the existing crown or veneer (if it’s intact and the fit is still appropriate), replacing a filling, or making a new restoration if the tooth needs better protection.

If decay or a crack is present, we’ll explain the findings and the most sensible way to stabilise the tooth long-term.

Sometimes, yes. If the crown is intact and the tooth underneath is healthy and stable, re-cementing can be a good option. If decay, a crack, or fit issues are present, replacing the crown may be safer long-term.

Mouthguards and retainers have different jobs, but both rely on precise fit to work properly. A custom mouthguard protects teeth and soft tissues during sport by distributing impact forces, while a retainer helps maintain tooth position after orthodontic treatment. We assess your bite, lifestyle needs and any existing dental work, then use impressions or digital scans to create an appliance that’s secure, comfortable and easy to clean. Regular review matters because appliances can wear, distort or stop fitting well as teeth change. The aim is predictable protection and long-term stability, not a quick off-the-shelf compromise.

currentText:
Feeling anxious about dental visits is extremely common — and it shows up in different ways.

Some people feel tense before appointments. Others avoid booking altogether. Some cope until something hurts, then worry about what they’ll be told. None of that is unusual, and none of it needs justifying.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, we take dental anxiety seriously — without making it the centre of the appointment.

Night guards and occlusal splints are custom-made appliances designed to protect teeth and reduce strain on the jaw.

They’re commonly used where tooth wear, clenching, grinding, or jaw discomfort is present, and where doing nothing may allow problems to progress.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, splints are used thoughtfully — as part of understanding and managing forces, not as a one-size-fits-all solution.
Custom-made appliances designed to protect teeth and reduce strain on the jaw.
Commonly used where tooth wear, clenching, grinding, or jaw discomfort is present, and where doing nothing may allow problems to progress.
Used thoughtfully as part of understanding and managing forces, not as a one-size-fits-all solution.
Night guards (occlusal splints)
night-guards-hero
Night guards and occlusal splints

Night guards and occlusal splints are used to protect teeth and manage risk when the bite is under strain.

They don’t “cure” grinding or clenching. Their role is more practical than that: to reduce damage, improve comfort, and help keep things stable over time when forces are higher than the teeth can comfortably tolerate.

Used appropriately, they form part of a longer-term management plan rather than a one-off fix.
We’ll take impressions or digital scans to ensure an accurate fit.
We’ll explain how and when to wear it, how to clean it, and what to expect initially.
Review appointments allow us to check comfort, fit, and effectiveness.

currentText: night-guards-who
Night guards are often recommended for people who show signs of tooth wear, repeated fractures, jaw discomfort, or muscle tension linked to clenching or grinding.

They’re also used when we see patterns that suggest ongoing risk, even if symptoms are mild. In other words, the decision isn’t based on one sore morning — it’s based on what the teeth and bite are telling us over time.
They are not appropriate for everyone, and they are not a substitute for addressing underlying dental or bite issues where those exist.

currentText:
Splints are most effective when they’re properly planned and reviewed.

We focus on careful assessment, accurate records, and follow-up to make sure the splint is doing what it’s intended to do. Adjustments may be needed over time as symptoms change or improve.

A splint is not usually a ‘fit once and forget’ device.

currentText: Our approach to splint therapy
night-guards-assessment
Our approach to splint therapy
Different types of splints
night-guards-types

A night guard is a custom-made appliance that fits over the teeth and is usually worn during sleep. Occlusal splints are similar appliances, sometimes designed for more specific bite control or daytime use.

fingerprint.startsWith: A night guard is a custom

currentText: They work by altering how the teeth contact each other and by spreading biting forces more evenly. This can reduce wear, chipping, muscle fatigue, and joint strain.
The design matters. A well-made appliance is planned around your bite, not selected off the shelf.
Different types of splints
Comfort and adjustment
night-guards-care
Wearing a night guard usually involves a short adjustment period. It may feel unfamiliar at first, and some people notice changes in how their bite feels when the appliance is removed in the morning.
The aim is comfort and protection, not forcing the jaw into a new position. We review how the appliance is working and make adjustments if needed.

fingerprint.startsWith: The aim is comfort and pr

currentText: Used properly, it should feel supportive rather than intrusive.
Comfort and adjustment

Night guards are a management tool, not a permanent solution to the cause of grinding.

They need to be checked periodically, as both the appliance and the bite can change over time. Wear on the guard often tells us useful information about ongoing forces.

In some cases, additional treatment or investigation is needed. In others, long-term use of a well-maintained appliance is an effective way of protecting the teeth and supporting comfort.
If you’re unsure whether a night guard or splint is necessary, we encourage you to ask.
Understanding why an appliance has been recommended — and what it can and can’t achieve — is key to making an informed decision.

currentText:
Orthodontic treatment focuses on improving how teeth are positioned, how they function together, and how they’re supported over time.

While many people associate orthodontics with straightening teeth for appearance, alignment can also play an important role in comfort, bite stability, tooth wear, and long-term oral health.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, orthodontic treatment is approached as part of a wider plan — not as a one-size-fits-all solution.
Improves tooth position and function
Supports comfort, bite stability, tooth wear, and long-term oral health

Orthodontic FAQs
Orthodontics may be considered when tooth position or bite contributes to crowding, spacing, bite imbalance, difficulty cleaning, or excessive wear.
Why might orthodontic treatment be recommended?
No. Many adults choose orthodontics later in life to address long-standing concerns or to support function and stability.
Is orthodontic treatment only for teenagers?
Options may include clear aligners, fixed appliances, or limited treatment focused on specific areas. Suitability depends on individual circumstances.
What types of orthodontic treatment are available?
Timescales vary depending on complexity, appliance type, and how teeth respond. We’ll give you a realistic estimate before starting.
How long does orthodontic treatment take?
Yes. Retainers help maintain the result and reduce the risk of teeth drifting over time.

currentText: Gum care focuses on reducing inflammation and protecting the bone and tissues that support your teeth. Gum disease often progresses quietly, with bleeding, bad breath or tenderness as early signs. We assess gum pocket depths, bleeding points and contributing factors such as smoking, medical conditions and bite stress, then recommend care based on your risk level. Treatment may include targeted cleaning below the gum line and guidance on brushing and interdental cleaning that’s realistic to maintain at home. The aim is to stabilise the condition, keep gums comfortable and reduce the chance of long-term problems such as mobility or tooth loss.
Full periodontal assessments with gentle charting and imaging
Non-surgical therapy focused on deep cleaning and root surface debridement
Personalised maintenance to keep gums, teeth, and implants stable
Periodontal & gum care
periodontal-hero
Calm, thorough gum care to steady teeth and implants
Why gum health matters
periodontal-importance
Gum disease is something we manage over time, not something we “fix” in a single visit.

In practice, the real work is understanding how your gums behave, spotting changes early, and keeping things stable long-term. That means looking at patterns, not reacting to one reading or one bad day.

fingerprint.endsWith: e reading or one bad day.

currentText: Periodontal care is about control and consistency. When it’s approached sensibly, most people can keep their gums and teeth functioning well for many years.
Stable gums protect your bite and overall health

Gum disease starts when the gums don’t tolerate plaque as well as they used to.

At first, that often shows up as bleeding or tenderness. Over time, if the irritation continues, the support around the teeth can begin to change. That’s when stability becomes the main concern rather than just appearance or comfort.

Not everyone progresses at the same rate. Some mouths are resilient, others less so. That variation is exactly why careful assessment matters.
We check for bleeding, plaque build-up, and gum measurements
X-rays or scans help us see bone levels where needed

Your periodontal pathway
periodontal-pathway
Assessing gum health is about context, not just numbers.
We record measurements around each tooth, note where bleeding occurs, and compare findings with previous visits. X-rays are used when they help explain what’s happening below the surface.
What matters most is whether things are stable, drifting, or actively changing. That trend guides sensible decisions far better than isolated figures.
Most patients stabilise with non-surgical care and regular maintenance when we work together on habits and reviews.
Non-surgical care first, with clear reviews

Ultrasonic scalers, fine hand instruments, and airflow-style finishing help remove plaque and calculus thoroughly. We use numbing gels or local anaesthetic when needed and share measured progress so you feel in control.

Maintenance & long-term stability
periodontal-maintenance
Managing gum disease usually starts with improving plaque control and carrying out thorough cleaning where it’s needed.

Sometimes that’s enough. In other cases, more focused treatment is required to reach areas that can’t be kept clean easily. This isn’t about escalation for its own sake — it’s about choosing the level of intervention that matches the level of risk.
The aim is to bring the condition under control and keep it there.

Periodontal FAQs
Treatment is planned gently with numbing gels or local anaesthetic where needed. You’ll be guided on what to expect and how to keep things comfortable afterwards.
Does deep cleaning hurt?
Gums often look and feel healthier within weeks, but long-term stability depends on regular maintenance and the risk factors we identify together.
How long does it take to see improvement?

currentText: Inflammation can reduce and pockets can tighten with good care. Recession usually needs protective maintenance rather than regrowth, and we’ll discuss options if grafting or referral is appropriate.
Can gum tissue grow back?
Peri-implant tissues can often be stabilised with careful cleaning, airflow-style stain removal, and close reviews. If advanced peri-implantitis is present, we’ll outline referral options calmly.

Polynucleotide FAQs
They are injectable biopolymers designed to support skin regeneration and hydration. We use regulated products and place them in superficial planes for gentle stimulation.
How do polynucleotides work?
Skin often feels more supple within weeks, with further improvements over a staged course. We review progress after each session.
When will I notice changes?

Often yes, when sequenced carefully. We may pair them with anti-wrinkle care (/treatments/anti-wrinkle-treatments) or skin boosters (/treatments/skin-boosters) in separate appointments if clinically appropriate.
Can I combine polynucleotides with other treatments?
No. We avoid treatment if you are pregnant, breastfeeding, unwell, or have skin infections. Suitability is confirmed during consultation.
Are polynucleotides suitable for everyone?
Effects are gradual and course-based. We review after each session and can pause further treatment if expectations are not aligned.
What if I do not like the outcome?

currentText: Preventative and general dentistry is about keeping problems small — or avoiding them altogether. A thorough check-up looks at teeth, gums, bite and soft tissues, alongside any symptoms or changes you’ve noticed. These visits help us spot early decay, gum inflammation and tooth wear before they become more complex to manage. Advice is tailored to your risk factors rather than generic rules, including daily cleaning technique, fluoride use, diet and habits that affect enamel and gum health. Where simple treatment is needed, we plan it carefully to keep teeth comfortable and easy to maintain, and we agree review intervals that suit your needs.

currentText:
Severe toothache can feel urgent, and it’s hard to think about anything else. Here in Shoreham-by-Sea, we see how quickly pain can disrupt sleep, eating, and work.

Pain relief can help you cope, but it doesn’t fix the underlying cause. Toothache can come from decay, infection, cracks, gum problems, grinding, or a filling or crown that’s failed.

We’ll assess what’s going on, explain what we can see, and recommend the most sensible way to settle pain and protect the tooth.
Identify the cause of pain
Relieve discomfort safely
Prevent the problem from worsening
Plan a realistic, durable fix
emergency_pain_overview
Severe toothache and dental pain

Toothache can range from mild twinges to severe, throbbing pain that disrupts sleep. If it’s persistent, worsening, or triggered by biting, heat, or cold, it’s worth getting checked even if it comes and goes.

We can talk through what’s happening and advise timing. If pain is getting worse, you notice swelling, fever, a bad taste, or you cannot open your mouth comfortably, call us promptly.

If you have rapid facial swelling, fever, difficulty swallowing, or breathing problems, seek urgent medical help immediately (A&E / 999) and then let us know as soon as you can.

What to do now

Pain often means the tooth or surrounding tissues are under stress.

Painkillers and temporary measures can take the edge off, but they cannot resolve infection, nerve damage, or structural problems such as cracks or failed restorations. The safest route is a proper assessment so the right treatment is chosen for you.

Our aim is to diagnose the cause accurately, settle pain, and help you avoid repeat flare-ups.
emergency_pain_importance
Prompt relief
Why assessment matters

At an emergency appointment we start with an assessment, look for the cause, and confirm a diagnosis with any checks or X-rays needed.

Where appropriate we provide immediate stabilisation to relieve pain and protect the tooth. Not all treatment is completed in one visit, so we’ll outline the next stages and timing.

Options may include replacing or repairing a filling, root canal treatment to treat infection inside the tooth, gum treatment, adjusting the bite, or in some cases removing a tooth that can’t be predictably saved.

We’ll explain the findings and the pros and cons of each option before anything is done.
emergency_pain_options
What we can do
Comfort-first care
Possible treatments

Sometimes pain eases for a while, but the cause may still be there. If pain is severe, waking you, lingering, or getting worse, it’s best to get advice promptly. Contact us and we’ll guide you on timing.

Skin booster FAQs
Boosters are runnier, hydrating injectables that improve skin texture rather than adding volume. We avoid mixing them with volume-driven fillers in the same plane.
How are boosters different from fillers?
Most patients notice improved hydration and suppleness after the first sessions, with further gains after the second or third treatment.
When will I see changes?
Often yes, when staged safely. We sequence treatments so skin can settle and prescription medicines remain effective.
Can they be combined with anti-wrinkle care?
We assess barrier health first. If skin is inflamed or compromised, we may delay boosters and focus on repair before proceeding.
What if I have sensitive skin?
Maintenance varies but top-ups are often recommended every few months once the initial course is complete.
How long do results last?

currentText: Sports mouthguards reduce the risk of chipped teeth, fractures, jaw injuries and soft tissue trauma during contact or high-impact sports. A custom-made guard is shaped to your bite so it stays in place, allows breathing and speaking more easily, and distributes impact forces more effectively than shop-bought options. We take impressions or digital scans, discuss thickness and sport-specific requirements, and ensure the fit is comfortable and secure. Mouthguards should be checked periodically, especially for younger patients or if teeth move over time. The goal is simple: reduce the chance of avoidable dental trauma during play.
Laboratory-crafted for reliable shock absorption
Tailored fit for your sport and dentition
Clear guidance on wear, storage, and replacement

Teeth whitening lightens the natural colour of teeth using peroxide-based gels, most commonly with custom trays worn at home and, in selected cases, an in-practice approach. Whitening works best when teeth and gums are healthy, so we begin with an assessment to check for decay, leaking fillings, gum inflammation, and causes of sensitivity. We explain what shade change is realistic for your starting colour and how results can be maintained with appropriate top-ups. Whitening does not change the colour of crowns, veneers, or fillings, so we plan around existing dental work and discuss options if a more even overall result is needed.
Custom-fit trays made from digital scans
UK-permitted gels prescribed and supervised by your dentist
Shade targets that respect enamel, gums, and existing restorations
Sequenced with aligners, bonding, or veneers so shade is locked in first
Teeth whitening
whitening-hero
Teeth whitening in Shoreham-by-Sea
Why dentist-led whitening matters
whitening-trust
Care delivered under UK regulations with prescriptions matched to your oral health

Clinical monitoring to stop treatment if sensitivity or concerns arise
Documentation that keeps results traceable for future smile work
Clinical oversight that keeps whitening safe

Teeth whitening is intended to lighten the natural colour of your teeth. It does not alter tooth structure; instead, it works by breaking down stains that have developed over time.

Results vary between individuals. Your starting shade, the type of staining present, and your overall oral health all influence how much lightening is possible.

Before starting, it is important to understand what whitening can and cannot achieve. A proper assessment helps confirm suitability and keeps expectations realistic.
Custom trays from digital scans for sealed, even gel placement
Planned, gradual whitening with check-ins to review comfort
Guidance to reduce sensitivity and protect gums
Advice on how whitening interacts with veneers, crowns, and fillings
Clear steps for top-ups using the same trays when indicated
Home whitening vs over-the-counter
whitening-overview
Measured change with custom trays and follow-up

Professional whitening uses regulated gels that penetrate the tooth surface and break down stain molecules.

The tooth is lightened from within rather than by removing enamel. When used under dental supervision, whitening is a controlled and predictable treatment.

Over-the-counter products may appear similar, but under UK regulations they are limited in strength and effectiveness.
Sensitivity management
whitening-technology
Staged whitening plan
Protocols that keep whitening comfortable

Not everyone is suitable for teeth whitening.

Teeth and gums need to be healthy before treatment. Whitening does not change the colour of fillings, crowns, or veneers, which can affect the overall appearance if these are present on visible teeth.

We assess your oral health, existing dental work, and the cause of discolouration before recommending whitening. In some cases, alternative treatments may be more appropriate.
Aligners or orthodontics establish positions before shade work
Whitening locks in a natural shade to match future composites or veneers
Composite or porcelain is planned after bleaching to avoid re-making restorations
Review points keep the plan compliant and comfortable at every stage

whitening-abc

Whitening questions
Whitening does not remove enamel when it is carried out under dental supervision. We assess your teeth and gums first and use regulated gels to keep treatment controlled and safe.
Does whitening damage enamel?
Sensitivity can happen during whitening, but it is usually temporary. We adjust wear times, use desensitising products, and pause treatment if needed to keep things comfortable.
Can whitening cause sensitivity?
Whitening results fade gradually over time and vary between people. We advise on habits that affect shade and discuss if or when a refresh might be appropriate.
How long do results last?

Safety, sensitivity, and longevity

Link whitening with follow-on care

Whitening is often surrounded by mixed advice online, so this page pulls the common questions into one clinically grounded place. We cover how whitening works, who it’s suitable for, what causes sensitivity, and how to approach whitening safely if you have gum recession, tooth wear, crowns or fillings. We also explain typical timelines, what “top-ups” actually mean, and how lifestyle factors such as coffee, tea and smoking affect stability of shade change. If you’re considering whitening as part of a wider smile plan, we’ll outline how it fits alongside aligners, bonding and veneers, so treatment is sequenced sensibly rather than rushed.

What to expect with existing restorations
How whitening supports smile makeovers

When prescribed and monitored by a dentist using UK-regulated gels, whitening is safe for enamel. We assess for decay or gum issues first and use protective trays.
Does whitening damage teeth?
We aim for a natural, even shade that suits your skin tone and enamel. Shade maps set a realistic range so we avoid over-whitening.

Results are maintained with good hygiene and occasional top-ups. We’ll guide you on a safe refresh schedule using your existing trays.
How long does whitening last?

currentText:
Problems involving the jaw joints (TMJ), clenching or grinding (bruxism), and facial muscle pain are common and often interconnected.

Symptoms can range from mild discomfort to persistent pain, headaches, or difficulty opening and closing the mouth.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, these issues are approached carefully, with an emphasis on understanding causes rather than jumping to conclusions.
Jaw joint, clenching, and facial pain can be linked
Symptoms range from mild discomfort to persistent pain
Care focuses on understanding causes first
TMJ & jaw care
tmj-jaw-hero
Jaw joint problems, clenching, and facial pain
Common symptoms
tmj-jaw-trust
Jaw or facial pain
Clicking or grating sounds from the jaw joints
Headaches, often on waking
Ear or temple discomfort
Tooth wear, fractures, or jaw stiffness
Common symptoms

The temporomandibular joints (TMJ) allow the jaw to move smoothly during speaking, chewing, and swallowing.

Bruxism refers to clenching or grinding of the teeth, often occurring during sleep but sometimes during waking hours.

Muscle activity, bite factors, stress, and habits can all influence how these systems behave. Rarely is there a single cause.
TMJ joints support smooth jaw movement
Bruxism is clenching or grinding, often during sleep
Muscle activity, bite, stress, and habits play a role

Tooth wear refers to the gradual loss of tooth structure over time.

It’s a common issue and often develops slowly, meaning many people don’t notice it until changes in shape, sensitivity, or appearance become more obvious.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, tooth wear is managed thoughtfully, with an emphasis on understanding why it’s happening before deciding how to treat it.
Tooth wear refers to the gradual loss of tooth structure over time
It often develops slowly before changes become more obvious
Care focuses on understanding why it’s happening before deciding how to treat it
tooth_wear_overview
Tooth wear and erosion
tooth_wear_causes
Factors contributing to tooth wear can include acidic foods or drinks, reflux, dry mouth, clenching or grinding, bite relationships, and lifestyle habits
Often, tooth wear results from a combination of influences rather than a single cause
Common causes
tooth_wear_symptoms
Tooth wear can occur for different reasons
Erosion is caused by acids softening the tooth surface
Attrition is wear from tooth-to-tooth contact, often linked to clenching or grinding
Abrasion involves mechanical wear, such as from brushing habits
More than one type of wear is often present at the same time

currentText: Different types of tooth wear

Understanding the cause and pattern of wear helps guide appropriate management.

Assessment may include examining how teeth meet, looking for signs of muscle activity, reviewing diet and habits, and checking for changes over time.

Not all wear requires immediate treatment, but monitoring is important.

If tooth wear is advanced or causing functional or comfort issues, treatment may be discussed.

Options can range from simple protective measures to restorative approaches designed to rebuild worn surfaces.

Any proposed treatment is planned carefully and staged where possible.
Treatment is considered when wear affects comfort or function

Tooth wear is usually a long-term consideration rather than a quick fix.

Ongoing review helps ensure that teeth remain comfortable and functional, and that any intervention remains appropriate as circumstances change.

Veneers are thin restorations placed on the front surface of teeth to refine shape, colour and alignment. They can be an excellent option when the teeth underneath are healthy enough, and when the plan is conservative and carefully staged. We start by understanding what you’d like to change, then assess enamel, bite, gum health and wear patterns so the result is stable and maintainable. In many cases, we can explore minimal-prep or additive approaches, or consider alternatives such as whitening, bonding, or aligners first. If veneers are suitable, we’ll talk through preview options, longevity factors and how to protect the finished work.
Natural-looking smiles tailored to your face
Minimal-prep options when clinically appropriate
Digital smile planning to preview outcomes

veneers-hero-intro
Dental veneers in Shoreham-by-Sea
Why patients trust our veneer planning
veneers-trust-signals
Planning led by clinicians who map bite, gum health, and enamel condition

Limitations & honesty
veneers-limitations
Veneers are not maintenance-free — hygiene visits and home care protect the margins and gumline.
Chipping, wear, or staining can happen, especially with strong bite forces or frequent dark foods and drinks.
Night guards are advised for clenching or grinding to protect edges and adhesive bonds.
Printed veneers are a more affordable step but not a lifetime solution; we set expectations for refresh or porcelain upgrades.

We review when whitening, composite bonding, or a full smile makeover may be safer alternatives for your goals (/treatments/teeth-whitening, /treatments/composite-bonding, /treatments/full-smile-makeover).
Clear boundaries so results stay predictable
Veneer FAQs

Longevity depends on material, bite forces, and maintenance. Porcelain can offer many stable years with night guard protection and reviews; digitally designed or composite-style veneers may need refreshes or upgrades sooner.
How long do veneers last?

Costs vary by material and complexity. Printed or composite-style options are the most affordable, while handcrafted porcelain reflects lab artistry and longevity. We outline options and payment plans before you commit.
How much do veneers cost?

Suitability depends on gum health, enamel thickness, bite, and habits. We may recommend whitening, composite bonding, orthodontics, or a full smile makeover instead if coverage is not the safest choice.
Am I suitable for veneers?

Routine hygiene, non-abrasive home care, and wearing a night guard if you clench all extend veneer life. Printed or composite-style veneers may need more frequent polishing or planned replacement; porcelain benefits from the same protective habits.
What maintenance do veneers need?

Porcelain veneers vs digitally designed / 3D printed veneers
veneers-porcelain-vs-printed
Longevity: porcelain is engineered for long-term wear; digitally designed or 3D printed veneers suit staged plans or shorter horizons.
Cost: printed options are more affordable upfront; porcelain reflects laboratory artistry and durability.
Repairability: printed and composite-style veneers can be repaired or refreshed; porcelain often needs replacement if a major chip occurs.

currentText: Thickness: porcelain can be ultra-thin yet strong; printed options are conservative but may need a little more thickness for stability.
Aesthetic ceiling: porcelain offers the highest translucency, texture, and colour layering; printed veneers provide a natural upgrade with a modest sheen.
Best suited: porcelain for long-term, high-demand smiles; printed for previews, budget-conscious stages, or when a full smile makeover is still being planned (/treatments/full-smile-makeover).
Choosing between ceramic longevity and staged printed options

Porcelain veneers are hand-layered in the lab with staining, characterisation, and glazing that suit your neighbouring teeth. Printed or milled options use FDA-cleared and CE-marked resins, then are hand finished chairside for gum harmony, bite integration, and a natural sheen.

If your teeth are sensitive, whitening may still be possible — but it needs careful planning and the right pacing. Sensitivity can come from exposed dentine, gum recession, enamel wear, micro-cracks, or underlying decay, so we start by identifying the cause rather than simply “pushing through”. We’ll talk you through lower-dose gels, shorter wear times, staged progress, and desensitising strategies to keep you comfortable. In some cases, addressing wear, bite stress or gum inflammation first makes whitening more predictable. If whitening isn’t the right option at the moment, we’ll explain alternatives and how to move towards it safely.

Whitening top-ups are short booster phases used after an initial course to maintain brightness over time. The need for top-ups varies — it depends on your starting shade, diet, staining habits, and how long you’d like the result to stay at a particular level. We’ll explain sensible intervals and how to avoid overuse, because more gel isn’t necessarily better and can increase sensitivity. If you already have custom trays, we can advise on appropriate gels and protocols; if not, we’ll assess your teeth and gums first. We’ll also discuss how top-ups interact with existing crowns or composite edges to keep your smile looking even.

Maintenance questions
Most patients refresh once or twice a year, often after hygiene visits. We tailor the schedule to your habits and starting shade.
How often should I top-up?
Yes, provided the fit is still secure. We’ll check for wear or gaps before supplying gel.
Can I reuse my old trays?

currentText: Usually not. We stick to safe, regulated strengths and keep to the smallest effective dose for your goals.

Keep maintenance aligned with your plan

A video consultation can be a calm first step if you’d like clinical guidance before coming into the practice.

It works well for discussing symptoms, reviewing your history, talking through options, and planning what would be most useful to do in person. If something needs a hands-on examination, X-rays or scans, we’ll be clear about that and help you book the right appointment.

A video consultation is not designed for emergencies, significant swelling, trauma, or situations where you may need urgent clinical care. In those cases, please call us so we can advise promptly.
Overview
Remote guidance with a clinician
Discuss discomfort, swelling, or sensitivity and assess urgency
Review recent photos or scans you can share securely
Explain likely causes and sensible self-care steps while you wait
Plan whether you need an in-practice visit and which appointment type fits best
Scope
What we can cover remotely
X-rays, detailed gum checks, and restorative treatment
Hands-on examination for bite, mobility, or soft-tissue changes
Urgent care that requires medication, procedures, or immediate assessment
